results.title: The Gathering
results.creator_credit: Randal Kleiser, Harry R Sherman and Hanna-Barbera Productions
results.brief_description: This feature length film made for television is a Christmas story with a difference. Adam Thornton (Ed Asner) walked out on his family years ago to focus his energies on his business career, leaving a wife and four children - two sons and two daughters. Thornton is a gruff, hard-headed man who finds out just before Christmas that he has a terminal illness and only a few weeks to live. On telling his estranged wife, Kate (Maureen Stapleton), it is agreed that a family reunion should take place over Christmas, but only on the proviso that his imminent death is not disclosed to his now four adult children. The story avoids a “sugary-sweet” tone by exploring the interaction between Thornton and each of his family members as he attempts to tentatively reconcile the past. He soon discovers that not everyone is totally forgiving but it is his wife who is the anchor, who holds the family together. Ed Asner and Maureen Stapleton are excellent in their roles and are accompanied by a very able support cast including Sarah Cunningham, Bruce Davison, Veronica Hamel, Gregory Harrison, Lawrence Pressman, John Randolph, Gail Strickland, Stephanie Zimbalist. (Awards: Emmy for Outstanding Special - Drama or Comedy, 1978)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Randal Kleiser, Harry R Sherman and Hanna-Barbera Productions

results.title: The General
results.creator_credit: Buster Keaton, Clyde Bruckman, Joseph Schenck, United Artists Corporation and Buster Keaton Productions
results.brief_description: Keaton’s best, and arguably the greatest screen comedy ever made. Against a meticulously evoked Civil War background, Buster risks life, limb and love as he pursues his beloved railway engine, hijacked by Northern spies up to no good for the Southern cause. The result is everything one could wish for; witty, dramatic, visually stunning, full of subtle, delightful human insights, and constantly hilarious. Cast includes Buster Keaton and Marion Mack. Rated: G

results.title: Ethics and the Media
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Journalism Resource Tapes”.
Creighton Burns, Editor of the Age and Harry Gordon, former Editor in Chief of the Herald and Weekly Times, discuss issues relating to journalism’s code of ethics. They discuss what their in-house rules are relating to ethics and integrity within their journalistic world.

results.title: Asphalt children...to all Sarajevians
results.brief_description: Vedrana is proud to be Yugoslavian, and proud to have been born in Sarajeva. To background images of Sarajeva, Vedrana reminisces about her childhood and growing up in the days of Tito - of her absolute belief in Yugoslavia where nationality did not matter. She asks “How could 1992 happen to Sarajeva, the most tolerant city in the world?”

results.title: Law Affecting Journalism
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Journalism Resource Tapes”.
Creighton Burns, Editor of “The Age”, and Harry Gordon, former Editor-in-Chief at “The Herald and Weekly Times”, discuss the law of libel, defamation, and the problems and benefits of these laws in the journalist’s world.

results.title: Sunday's dog
results.creator_credit: Fionnuala Keith, Maddie Jamieson Goddard and Pepper Horman
results.brief_description:
When Sunday went to live with her grandmother she didn’t have any friends to play with. One day a stray dog walked down the lane behind her house. It was missing a tail and an ear. Nobody wanted it. Sunday made friends with the dog but it was taken away to the pound. Weeks passed. Dogs were adopted and other dogs were led away to a big blue door. Finally, Sunday found the dog at the pound and adopted him. When they got home, Sunday made him a special hat with two ears and a tail for him to wag. Creators: Pepper Horman, Maddie Jamieson Goddard, Fionnuala Keith, Jennifer Petroploulos, Lucy Hanna, Declan Warren, Piper McLeod, Amy Phillips, Elan Cotter, Georgia Dickie, Isabella Godfrey, Lucinda McSherry, Millie Barnes, Nick Warren, Ella O’Donoghue, Isobel Hyett, Michael Guzzardi, Lucy Phillips, Clare Olding and Jagger Skilbeck.

Under the category ‘Primary Animation’, Years 5 and 6, Yarraville West Primary School, Victoria, were the Screen It 2012 winners.
